subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I manage someone with the long-term effects of COVID-19?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Definitions

  • Acute COVID-19 is defined as signs and symptoms of infection for up to the first 4 weeks.
  • Ongoing symptomatic COVID-19 is defined as signs and symptoms of infection from 4–12 weeks.
  • Post-COVID-19 syndrome is defined as signs and symptoms of infection consistent with COVID-19 lasting longer than 12 weeks.
  • Long COVID is defined as signs and symptoms persisting after the first 4 weeks, so encompasses both ongoing symptomatic and post-COVID-19 syndrome.

Symptoms

  • Symptoms after acute COVID-19 are variable and wide ranging. The most commonly reported symptoms include:
    • Generalized symptoms
      • Fatigue.
      • Fever.
      • Pain.
    • Respiratory
      • Breathlessness.
      • Cough.
    • Cardiovascular
      • Chest tightness.
      • Chest pain.
      • Palpitations.
    • Neurological
      • Cognitive impairment such as loss of concentration and memory issues.
      • Headache.
      • Sleep disturbance.
      • Peripheral neuropathy including paraesthesia and numbness.
      • Dizziness.
      • Delirium (in older people).
    • Gastrointestinal 
      • Abdominal pain.
      • Nausea.
      • Diarrhoea.
      • Anorexia and reduced appetite (in older people).
    • Musculoskeletal
      • Joint and muscle pains.
    • Psychological 
      • Depression and anxiety.
    • Ear, nose, and throat
      • Tinnitus.
      • Ear ache.
      • Sore throat.
      • Loss of taste and/or smell.
    • Dermatological
      • Skin rashes.

Assessment

  • When taking a history ask about:
    • The disease history, duration, and onset of COVID-19 including previous and current symptoms.
    • Co-morbidities.
    • Impact on daily life.
    • Deterioration in general condition physically, psychologically, and socially.
  • If the person reports or demonstrates impaired cognition use a validated screening tool to measure severity of impairment and impact. 
  • Suspect previous COVID‑19 illness as a possible underlying cause of new or ongoing symptoms in people after acute COVID‑19 if they have either:
    • Ongoing symptomatic COVID-19 4–12 weeks after the start of acute COVID-19, or
    • Post-COVID-19 syndrome if symptoms have not resolved 12 weeks after the start of acute COVID-19.

Investigations

  • Investigations of people with ongoing or post-COVID-19 syndrome should be focused on ruling out acute, life-threatening complications or to evaluate the possibility of either persisting COVID-19 sequelae or a new and unrelated diagnosis. 
  • Consider offering blood tests including:
    • Full blood count.
    • Urea and electrolytes.
    • Liver function tests.
    • C-reactive protein test.
    • Ferritin level.
    • B-type natriuretic peptide.
    • Thyroid function tests.
  • Additionally, it may be appropriate to consider an exercise tolerance test to assess breathlessness, heart rate changes, and oxygen saturation. 
  • For people with postural symptoms an assessment of lying and standing blood pressure may be helpful to exclude postural hypotension, postural tachycardia, or other forms of autonomic dysfunction. 
  • If a person has persisting respiratory symptoms lasting longer than 12 weeks after acute COVID-19 you should arrange a chest X-ray. 

Management and referral

  • People who have suspected or confirmed COVID-19 should be given advice and written information on the common symptoms of COVID-19 and after acute COVID-19, the likely timeline of recovery, depending on the severity of their illness, and how to manage ongoing symptoms. A shared decision-making approach should be used to inform follow up and review, particularly if symptoms of COVID-19 persist beyond 4 weeks of the initial presentation. 

Urgent referral

  • Refer people with ongoing symptomatic COVID-19 or suspected post-COVID-19 syndrome urgently if they have signs or symptoms that could be caused by an acute or life‑threatening complication, including:
    • Severe hypoxaemia or oxygen desaturation on exercise.
    • Signs of severe lung disease.
    • Cardiac chest pain.
    • Multisystem inflammatory syndrome (in children).
    • Severe psychiatric symptoms or at risk of self-harm or suicide.

Other specialist referral

  • For people who do not need urgent referral consider referral to the appropriate local services for people who:
    • Have anxiety, depression, or more complex psychological needs (or complex physical and mental health presentations).
    • May benefit from a multidisciplinary assessment service.
    • May benefit from specialist care for specific complications.
  • Note that you should not exclude referrals for further specialist input based on the absence of a positive SARS-CoV-2 test. 

Management and self-management

  • Give advice and information on self-management to people with ongoing symptomatic COVID‑19 or post‑COVID‑19 syndrome including:
    • Ways to self-manage their symptoms, such as setting realistic goals.
    • Who to contact if they are worried about their symptoms or need support with self‑management.
    • Sources of advice and support, including support groups and social prescribing.
    • Signposting support from other services, including advice on social care, housing, and employment, and financial support.
    • Information about new or continuing symptoms of COVID-19.
  • Explain to people there is no evidence for over-the-counter vitamins or supplements for the treatment of new or ongoing symptoms of COVID‑19.
  • Support people in discussions with their employer, school, or college about returning to work or education, for example by having a phased return. 

Follow up

  • Agree with the person how often follow up is needed, and which healthcare professionals should be involved. 
  • Tailor follow up to people's symptoms and discuss any changes, including new or worsening symptoms and the effects of these on the person's life and wellbeing.
  • Consider supported self-monitoring at home, for example heart rate, blood pressure, and pulse oximetry, if this is appropriate as part of the person's assessment. Ensure that people have clear instructions and threshold parameters for when to seek further help.
  • Be alert to symptoms developing that could mean referral or investigation is needed.
  • Note for people who have been admitted to hospital with acute COVID-19 a healthcare professional in secondary care should offer a video or phone follow‑up consultation at 6 weeks after discharge to check for new or ongoing symptoms or complications.

subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on COVID-19 rapid guideline: managing the long-term effects of COVID-19 [NICE, 2020n].
